entry.title: Re: Smarter Built-In Support in C4C: A Unified and Upgraded Experience
entry.content:
Thanks for taking the time to share this. I really understand why the change feels disruptive, especially if you were used to handling everything inside C4C without ever needing SAP for Me. The extra step of customer authorization can feel inconvenient at first, but it is worth remembering that using S-users has always been a requirement, particularly whenever you need support access on a tenant you cannot log into. Another positive and important aspect, which was not mentioned in the blog, is that your cases will now remain available even if you refresh or move your tenant, which was not possible before.

It is also important to say that the previous Built-In Support platform was outdated with no possibility of improvement and was affected by synchronization issues that caused real problems for many customers. This was one of the key reasons why we needed to move to a more reliable foundation, a foundation that is used in multiple SAP solutions.

Just to clarify, this is not a full shift to SAP for Me. You can still create and manage your own cases directly within the application. For managing all cases created by other admin users, aligning C4C with the broader SAP support platform now gives you access to the full case management capabilities of SAP for Me, including far better reporting, clearer escalation paths, and a much more reliable overall experience.

I really appreciate your feedback, it helps us support everyone better through the transition.

entry.title: Can we send an inspection record for every SFC without using inspection points in SAP DM?
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I would like to ask whether it is possible to send an inspection record for every SFC without using inspection points in SAP DM.

Case:

We have a production order with a planned quantity of 5. Since the lot size is 1, SAP DM creates 5 separate SFCs. Quality inspection characteristics are assigned to the first operation.

We are able to successfully send Inspection Results Recording for the first SFC.
However, when we try to send inspection results for the second SFC in the same operation, we receive an error.

Does this mean that an inspection can only be recorded once unless inspection points are used?
Is there any standard way to submit inspection results for each SFC without using inspection points?

Footnote: We use Work Center POD for recording inspection results. Also, inspection points are only supported in the Order POD.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Emir.

entry.title: Is there any standard way to send rework quantities or times from SAP DM to SAP during execution?
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I would like to ask about the standard capabilities of SAP Digital Manufacturing regarding rework confirmations.

In SAP DM, we know there are several standard approaches for handling rework, such as:

  • Disposition-based rework,

  • In-routing rework loops, etc.

If the routing does not contain a dedicated rework operation, SAP DM does not send any rework quantity or rework time to SAP ERP. All confirmations are treated as normal confirmations, and there is no standard flag or indicator to differentiate a ‚Äúsecond time‚Äù confirmation from a rework one.

Is there any standard functionality in SAP DM that allows us to send rework quantities or rework time to SAP side during execution, even when the rework operation is not defined in the original routing?

Any guidance, clarification, or experience-sharing would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Clean Core Index, measure usage of SAPScript and SmartForms
entry.content:
Introduction

As part of our Custom Code Lifecycle Management, and especially as part of our Clean Core journey, we try to delete as many obsolete objects as possible. In the end, we try to get rid of almost 30 years of custom development.

Before we can start to renovate our code, we first need to identify and delete any unused object. SAP supports us on this with various tools, like UPL, CCLM on Solution Manager  or the Custom Code Migration app. Sadly, none of the tools is 100% perfect in identifying unused code. For example, classical print reports will be flagged as unused, even if you use them on daily basis. This is because the user doesn't call the report itself. Instead, it gets called in a dynamical manner, after reading the name of report from the customizing

So how can we identify, if a SAPScript or SmartForm is really in use? I wasn't able to find any standard solution. Therefore I created a little tool by myself I want to share with you.

Disclaimer

My solution works on an on-premise system (S/4 HANA 2023 FP1). It consists of few development objects and some of them violates Clean Core principles. Sometimes you need to take a bad pill.

The main work was found in this community post. Thanks to DavidLY for showcasing this

Theory

Each form gets created by some code, typically a dedicated print report. If such a report gets called dynamically, i.e., based on some customizing settings, UPL will not count this as a usage. Same is also true for the forms itself. Often the name of a form to use is configured by customizing. Even if you try to use ABAP code search in ADT, to find a report related to a given form, there is a good chance to get no result.

So how do we know if a given form is still in use or already obsolete and unused since years? In my opinion, one must inspect all created spool objects and try to read the name of the form based on TemSe data.

To access the header information and content of a spool job, tables TST01 and TST03 can be used. Field DTYPE in TST01 indicates the type of spool data. If it starts with OTF%, it is either SAPScript or SmartForms. By this, we know that this is a form, but we still need to find the name of the form used to create the spool. This can be read from content of spool (table TST03).

You can check this by transaction SP01. Double-click on one spool job to open the header information

Navigate to tab "TemSe object" and double-click on spool object name

This will open the list of objects inside the spool request. Mark one object and click on button Contents to inspect the content itself

Have a close look at the second row. You'll find the name of the form, in this example, the name was ZMEDRUCK_US

Similar works also for SmartForms.

As we now know how to identify the form used to create a spool object, we can develop some artifacts to fetch them automatically.

Solution

CDS View

First of all, a CDS view is used to read the spool files and their content. This will be the basis for further processing.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'List of actively used SAPScript forms'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define root view entity ZI_cclm_upl_sapscript
  as select from tst01 as spool
    join         tst03 as data on  spool.dname = data.dname
                               and spool.dpart = data.dpart
{
key spool.dname as SpoolName,
                             key spool.dpart as SpoolPart,
                             key data.drowno as SpoolNo,
                             spool.dtype as SpoolType,
                             spool.dlang as Language,
                             cast( substring( spool.dcretime, 1, 8) as abap.dats ) as CreatedAt,
                             spool.dmodtool as Report,
                             spool.dcreater as CreatedBy,
                            
                             data.ddatalen as DataLength,
                             data.dcontent as Content

  }
where
      spool.dtype like 'OTF%'
  and data.drowno = 1

 

Class

The following class is used to read and process the data. It provides methods to read spool usage per day as well as methods to extract form name based on spool content.

 

We run this code on a daily basis and store the results in a custom table. As this might be different to your requirement, I only provide a method stub for this. You might want to add whatever code you like to store the result.

"! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Class to extract usage of SAPScript forms</p>
"! This class is part of BOMAGs clean core strategy. It helps to collect all actively used
"! SAPScript forms. With this class, the results can be stored in table ZSSTAT
CLASS zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    TYPES:
      "! data type for usage statistic
      BEGIN OF
        ty_usage,

        sapscriptform TYPE swncentryid,
        report        TYPE progname,
        lastcreatedat TYPE date,
        lastcreatedby TYPE syuname,
        totalusage    TYPE int4,
      END OF ty_usage.

    "! Table type for usage statistics aggregated by user, date and SAPScript form
    TYPES tyt_usage TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_usage WITH KEY sapscriptform.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">get SAPscript usage by date</p>
    "! This method reads all existing TemSe objects to collect all used SAPScript
    "! forms during the diven time period.
    "! This method can't be used to query historical data stored in ZSSTAT. Instead
    "! it can be used to read actual data
    "! @parameter usage_from | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">spool created from date</p>
    "! @parameter usage_to   | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">spool created to date</p>
    "! @parameter usage      | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">table containing aggregated data</p>
    METHODS get_actual_usage_by_date IMPORTING usage_from   TYPE sydate
                                               usage_to     TYPE sydate
                                     RETURNING VALUE(usage) TYPE tyt_usage.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Persist usage statistics to database</p>
    "! This method can be used to store usage statistics to database. It stores actual usage statistics to
    "! table ZSSTAT. If record already exists, it gets aggregated (update), otehrwise it creates new records
    "! @parameter usage_list | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">List with actual usage data to store</p>
    METHODS write_usage_to_db IMPORTING usage_list TYPE tyt_usage.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    TYPES:
      "! data type for single spool entry, no aggregated data
      BEGIN OF ty_non_aggregated_usage,
        spool         TYPE zi_cclm_upl_sapscript,
        sapscriptform TYPE tdname,
      END OF ty_non_aggregated_usage.

    "! Table type for spool entries, no aggregation
    TYPES tyt_non_aggreageted_usage TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_non_aggregated_usage.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Get SAPScript form name by content</p>
    "! This method can be used to determine SAPScript form name based on spool content
    "! (content of TemSe object)
    "! @parameter content   | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">content of TemSe object</p>
    "! @parameter form_name | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Name of SAPScript form</p>
    METHODS get_sapscript_name IMPORTING content          TYPE string
                               RETURNING VALUE(form_name) TYPE tdform.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Aggregate usage statistic</p>
    "! This method aggregates (sum) actual usage data to one row for each date, user and SAPScript
    "! @parameter spool | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">list of non aggregated usage data</p>
    "! @parameter usage | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">aggregated usage data</p>
    METHODS aggregate_usage IMPORTING !spool       TYPE tyt_non_aggreageted_usage
                            RETURNING VALUE(usage) TYPE tyt_usage.

ENDCLASS.


CLASS zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD get_actual_usage_by_date.
    DATA spool TYPE tyt_non_aggreageted_usage.

    SELECT * FROM zi_cclm_upl_sapscript
      WHERE createdat BETWEEN @usage_from AND @usage_to
      INTO TABLE (sapscript_list).

    LOOP AT sapscript_list ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<single_form>).

      IF <single_form>-datalength <= 0.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      DATA(encoded_content) = ||.

      " prepare conversion RAW to STRING
      DATA(encoded_object) = cl_abap_conv_in_ce=>create( encoding = '4103'
                                                         input    = <single_form>-content ).

      " convert RAW to string
      encoded_object->read( IMPORTING data = encoded_content ).

      DATA(formname) = get_sapscript_name( substring( val = encoded_content
                                                      len = 1000 ) ).

      spool = VALUE #( BASE spool
                       ( spool         = <single_form>
                         sapscriptform = formname )  ).

      CLEAR formname.
    ENDLOOP.

    usage = aggregate_usage( spool  ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD get_sapscript_name.
    " SAPScript
    FIND 'IN01' IN content MATCH OFFSET DATA(pos).
    IF pos > 0.
    ELSE.
      " SmartForm
      FIND 'IN04' IN content MATCH OFFSET pos.
    ENDIF.

    IF pos > 0.
      pos += 5.
      form_name = substring( val = content
                             off = pos
                             len = 16 ).
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD aggregate_usage.
    LOOP AT spool ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<spool>).

      " try to get last usage of a given form, user and date
      ASSIGN usage[ sapscriptform = <spool>-sapscriptform
                    lastcreatedby = <spool>-spool-createdby
                    lastcreatedat = <spool>-spool-createdat ] TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<usage>).

      " record already found, aggregate
      IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <usage> IS ASSIGNED.
        <usage>-totalusage += 1.
        <usage>-report      = <spool>-spool-report.
      ELSE.
        " new record, add to list
        usage = VALUE #( BASE usage
                         ( sapscriptform = <spool>-sapscriptform
                           report        = <spool>-spool-report
                           lastcreatedat = <spool>-spool-createdat
                           lastcreatedby = <spool>-spool-createdby
                           totalusage    = 1 ) ).
      ENDIF.

      UNASSIGN <usage>.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD write_usage_to_db.
    " 1. read all existing records from ZSSTAT to update these
    IF lines( usage_list ) > 0.
      SELECT * FROM zsstat
        FOR ALL ENTRIES IN @usage_list
        WHERE sysid    = -sysid
          AND zdate    = @usage_list-lastcreatedat
          AND account  = @usage_list-lastcreatedby
          AND entry_id = @usage_list-sapscriptform
          AND tcode    = 'SAPSCRIPT'
        INTO TABLE (usage_statistics).
    ENDIF.

    " 2 .loop through newly aggregated usage statistics
    LOOP AT usage_list ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<new_usage_record>).

      ASSIGN usage_statistics[ sysid    = sy-sysid
                               entry_id = <new_usage_record>-sapscriptform
                               account  = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedby
                               zdate    = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedat ] TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<usage>).

      " 2.1 update existing record in database
      IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <usage> IS ASSIGNED.
        <usage>-zcount += <new_usage_record>-totalusage.
        UPDATE zsstat
        SET zcount = <usage>-zcount
            progname = <new_usage_record>-report
        WHERE sysid    = sy-sysid
          AND zdate    = <usage>-zdate
          AND account  = <usage>-account
          AND entry_id = <usage>-entry_id
          AND tcode    = 'SAPSCRIPT'.
      ELSE.

        " 2.2. insert new record to database
        INSERT INTO zsstat VALUES @( VALUE #(
                                        sysid = sy-sysid
                                        zdate = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedat
                                        account = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedby
                                        entry_id = <new_usage_record>-sapscriptform
                                        tcode = 'SAPSCRIPT'
                                        zcount = <new_usage_record>-totalusage
                                        progname = <new_usage_record>-report ) ).

      ENDIF.
      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        COMMIT WORK.
      ENDIF.

      UNASSIGN <usage>.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

Report

We want to create a usage statistics. This means we need to read data for a certain period on a regular basis (like once per day). As we're on-premise, we need to schedule a job and therefore, we need a small report which uses the class above.

REPORT zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript_aggr.

PARAMETERS:
  pm_from TYPE dats,
  pm_to   TYPE dats.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  DATA(upl) = NEW zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript( ).

  DATA(usage) = upl->get_actual_usage_by_date( usage_from = pm_from
                                               usage_to   = pm_to ).
  upl->write_usage_to_db( usage_list = usage ).

  LOOP AT usage ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<usage>).

    WRITE: / <usage>-lastcreatedat,
    <usage>-lastcreatedby,
    <usage>-sapscriptform,
    <usage>-report,
    <usage>-totalusage.
  ENDLOOP.

Conclusion

Thanks to these small development artifacts, we build a reliable usage statistics for SAPScript and SmartForms. After collecting data for almost 12 months, we now know the forms actively used.

 

I'm still looking for a similar solution for Adobe Forms. If one has some idea on how to check usage here as well, please let me know

entry.title: SAP Transportation Management Clean Core Evolution
entry.content:
SAP Transportation Management Clean Core Evolution

Introduction

SAP Transportation Management (TM) is undergoing a transformative evolution through the Clean Core (What is a clean core? | SAP) initiative, fundamentally changing how organizations approach transportation order processing and data management. This comprehensive analysis examines five critical SAP Notes that collectively establish the foundation for modern, Clean Core-compliant TOR (Transportation Order) processing in S/4HANA 2025.

These interconnected notes represent a strategic shift from traditional transportation processing to a standardized, API-first architecture that leverages Virtual Data Model (VDM) CDS views, RESTful Application Programming (RAP) objects, and enhanced cross-module integration capabilities. Organizations implementing or upgrading SAP TM will benefit significantly from understanding how these notes work together to create a robust, future-ready transportation management platform.

Find out about the purpose and key ingredients of a clean core in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition. Explore how you can get and stay ‚Äúclean core compliant,‚Äù and discover the advantages you gain by following the clean core principles, with the focus on clean core extensibility.

Clean Core: What It Is, Why to Do It, and How to Get There

SAP Notes Overview

SAP Note 3619960 - Clean Core TOR Transportation Processing VDM CDS View + RAP Objects

Purpose

This note delivers new Transportation Processing (TP) layer VDM CDS views along with comprehensive RAP objects specifically designed for transportation order management. It establishes the core processing layer that enables modern, API-first transportation order handling while maintaining strict Clean Core compliance.

Key Components

The note introduces several critical TP views including R_TransportationOrderTP_2, R_TransportationOrderItemTP_2, R_TransportationOrderStopTP_2, R_TransportationOrderEventTP_2, R_TransportationOrderStageTP_2, R_TranspOrdDocRefTP_2, and R_TranspOrdItemDocRefTP_2. Additionally, it delivers BDEF R_TRANSPORTATIONORDERTP_2 with comprehensive RAP objects including behavior implementation pools (BP_R_TRANSPORD*TP_2), behavior handler classes, and entity handler classes.

Prerequisites

This note requires Clean Core TOR Foundation layer VDM CDS views available from S/4HANA 2025 FPS0, establishing a clear dependency hierarchy that must be followed during implementation.

SAP Note 3620011 - BDC/Data Produtores/4 2025 FPS1

Purpose

This note enhances the Business Data Catalog (BDC) framework and introduces advanced data product capabilities specifically for Transportation Order processing in S/4HANA 2025 FPS1, enabling standardized data exchange and improved integration patterns.

Key Features

The implementation focuses on enhanced data product framework for TOR objects, improved integration capabilities with external systems, standardized data exchange mechanisms, and performance optimizations for large-scale transportation operations. This creates a foundation for seamless data consumption across hybrid landscapes.

SAP Note 3546383 - Clean Core TOR_CDS View Foundation_OP25FSP0

Purpose

This foundational note contains new Clean Core Transportation Order Management foundation layer CDS views delivered in S/4HANA 2025 FPS0. It establishes the base data model structure upon which all subsequent transportation processing enhancements are built.

Core Components

The note delivers fundamental CDS views that provide base transportation order data structures, standardized field definitions and relationships, authorization framework integration, and performance-optimized data access patterns. As the foundation layer, this note serves as a prerequisite for other transportation processing enhancements.

SAP Note 3675099 - Downport Location VDM to EWE (2025/FPS1)

Purpose

This note addresses the downporting of Location VDM capabilities to Extended Warehouse Environment (EWE) for S/4HANA 2025 FPS1, ensuring consistent location data management across transportation and warehouse management modules.

EWE Integration

The note delivers new CDS views for Location and Transportation Location including I_LocationBasic_2, I_LocationText_2, I_LocationType, I_TransportationLocation_2, and I_TranspLocationType_2. These views become available when the corresponding Support Package is installed, providing seamless integration between TM and EWM location master data.

SAP Note 3677186 - Clean Core Location CDS View Foundation - OP2025 FPS1

Purpose

This note provides enhanced Clean Core Location CDS view foundation for S/4HANA 2025 FPS1, delivering corrections and enhancements to the location data model established in the previous note.

Foundation Components

The note delivers the same core location CDS views as Note 3675099 but includes corrections and enhancements. This ensures robust location master data management with improved data consistency and enhanced integration capabilities across transportation and warehouse management modules.

Comparative Analysis

Aspect

Note 3619960

Note 3620011

Note 3546383

Note 3675099

Note 3677186

Primary Focus

TP Layer Processing

BDC/Data Products

Foundation Layer

Location VDM Downport

Location Foundation Enhancement

Release Target

S/4HANA 2025+

S/4HANA 2025 FPS1

S/4HANA 2025 FPS0

S/4HANA 2025 FPS1

S/4HANA 2025 FPS1

Technical Layer

Processing/RAP

Integration/BDC

Foundation/VDM

Cross-Module/VDM

Foundation/VDM

Dependencies

Requires 3546383

Independent

Foundation for others

Independent

Enhancement of 3675099

Business Impact

Core TOR Processing

Data Integration

Base Architecture

Location Consistency

Enhanced Location Management

Implementation Roadmap

Phase 1: Foundation Setup

  1. Apply SAP Note 3546383 to establish Clean Core TOR Foundation layer CDS views
  2. Validate base transportation order data structures through transaction SE11
  3. Configure authorization framework and verify data access permissions
  4. Perform initial testing of foundation layer functionality
  5. Document baseline system configuration for future reference

Phase 2: Core Processing Enhancement

  1. Implement SAP Note 3619960 for Transportation Processing layer
  2. Deploy VDM CDS views and validate data consistency across all transportation objects
  3. Configure RAP objects including behavior definitions and handler classes
  4. Test CRUD operations through RAP framework with comprehensive error handling
  5. Validate business logic implementation and integration points

Phase 3: Data Product Integration

  1. Apply SAP Note 3620011 for BDC/Data Product capabilities
  2. Configure data product framework for TOR objects with appropriate governance controls
  3. Test integration scenarios with external systems and validate data quality
  4. Implement monitoring and alerting for data product consumption
  5. Establish data governance policies and procedures

Phase 4: Location Management Integration

  1. Implement SAP Note 3675099 for Location VDM downport
  2. Apply SAP Note 3677186 for enhanced location foundation
  3. Configure EWE integration points and validate location data synchronization
  4. Test cross-module consistency between TM and EWM
  5. Validate location master data harmonization across all modules

Phase 5: Complete System Validation

  1. Perform comprehensive end-to-end testing across all implemented components
  2. Conduct performance validation under realistic load conditions
  3. Execute user acceptance testing with business stakeholders
  4. Prepare go-live procedures and rollback plans
  5. Establish ongoing monitoring and maintenance procedures

Technical Architecture Impact

VDM Layer Evolution

The progression from foundation (Note 3546383) to processing layer (Note 3619960) creates a robust, layered architecture that separates concerns while maintaining data consistency. This evolution enables better performance through optimized data access patterns and provides clear extension points for custom requirements while adhering to Clean Core principles.

RAP Framework Integration

The introduction of RAP objects in Note 3619960 enables modern service exposure capabilities, encapsulates business logic effectively, and provides standardized API access patterns. This framework supports both OData and REST protocols, making transportation data accessible to various client technologies while maintaining upgrade stability.

Cross-Module Integration

The location VDM implementation (Notes 3675099 and 3677186) ensures data consistency between Transportation Management and Extended Warehouse Management, creating a unified location master data approach that reduces data redundancy and improves data quality across modules.

Benefits and Value Proposition

Clean Core Compliance

  • Reduced customization complexity through standardized extension points and approved APIs
  • Improved upgrade compatibility by eliminating core modifications and technical debt
  • Standardized data models that align with SAP's strategic technology direction
  • Future-ready architecture supporting seamless cloud migration scenarios

Performance Improvements

  • Optimized data access patterns through VD
  • Support documentation for this topic

 CDS Views for Fixed Domain | SAP Help Portal For SAP Transportation Management

3662211 - Clean core enhancement capabilities and MTr consideration for TRS and NPD - SAP for Me

3675099 - Downport Location VDM to EWE (2025/FPS1) - SAP for Me

3619960 - Clean Core TOR Transportation Processing VDM CDS View + RAP objects - SAP for Me

3546383 - Clean Core TOR_CDS View Foundation_OP25FSP0 - SAP for Me

3677186 - Clean Core Location CDS view foundation - OP2025 FPS1 - SAP for Me

Hope this support you.

Kind regards

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Tracing Fields & Data Tables for WBS Elements
entry.content:
Hello,

 

I am new to SAP and SAP Hana, so please bear with me as I try my best to explain what I am hoping to accomplish:

 

Our SCM team does a lot of manual work creating part reports each day (over 20 hours/week alone) and I am working to find ways to automate those processes. There are still manual feeds into these reports that SAP cannot maintain, so I figured it might be best to do the reports in Excel and use formulas to query the SAP databases. That being said, I am trying to trace the location of certain fields in SAP to the table & field names in SAP Hana to know where to query my database and link things together. I have put a table below of the fields that I am looking for and where I have found some of them but others I have not found. 

Field Description

Table Name

Field Name

Screen Location

Part Number

MAKT

MATNR

Stock/Requirements List: Initial Screen

Description

MAKT

MAKTX

Stock/Requirements List

Supplier Code

EINA

MATNR

To Retrieve LIFNR

Supplier Name

LFA1

LIFNR

 

QOH

MARD

LABST (but the number is incorrect)

Stock/Requirements List

Minor Model

 

MAJOR_MODEL

This is located on Production Order Display: Header, but I have to go to Header and then Configuration to get the Characteristic Value Assignment to show up. When I click F1, it opens a values screen but that doesn't help either

Required Date on Floor

MDEZ

DAT00

This is the Date Column on Stock/Requirements List. F1 says MDEZ-DAT00 but I don't have MDEZ in SAP Hana.

Delivery Date of Final Assembly Shipment

 

 

I need to trace the line unit number below to it's Sales Order Line and then determine when the contracted delivery date is.

Line Units

 

 

This comes from a WBS Element that I cannot determine where it compiles the data from.  On the Production Order Display: Header screen, under assignment and then section "assignments", there is a WBS Element. The number I need is digits 9-12 of that element and then that number should trace back to a sales order line item number. F1 says the table and field are: AFPOD-PROJN but when I go to that table, the string of data doesn't exist. 

I hope all of this makes sense but if not, I am sorry. I tried to break it down the best I could at this time.

entry.title: Output Parameters for Handling Unit Label Printing in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello experts,

I am trying to print a handling unit (HU) label in SAP Public Cloud via an outbound delivery using the EXTOM channel. However, when processing it in BarTender, I am missing the printer and the label type that should be printed.

I have already used a BAdI to extend the output parameters and successfully added some missing information. However, I would like to have additional details available in the output parameter determination, such as warehouse number, HU type, step, etc., because with these data I could determine which form to send and specify a printer.

Is there a way to include these fields in the generated output file? Any guidance or examples would be greatly appreciated.

Etiqueta de UMp (HU_LABEL) | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: How to Configure Local Currency and Thresholds in KPIs for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hello everyone,
I‚Äôm currently working on setting up KPIs and reports in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and I‚Äôve encountered two issues that I haven‚Äôt been able to resolve with the available documentation:

Changing the currency of standard KPIs:
Several KPIs are currently configured with EUR as the default currency. When I try to edit the KPI to switch the currency to our company code currency (COP), the system does not allow me to select another currency.

Is there a way to modify the base currency of these standard KPIs?

Is there something additional that needs to be configured in Manage KPIs and Reports or at the semantic layer (CDS Views / Analytical Queries)?

Setting thresholds and visual limits:
I need to define threshold ranges (optimal, warning, alert) so that these KPIs visually reflect performance levels. However, I haven‚Äôt found a clear place to configure these thresholds.

In which application or section can these KPI thresholds be maintained?

Does this work the same way for both standard and custom KPIs?

Any guidance, best practices, or official documentation references to help address these points would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support!

entry.title: Re: Silent install of Hana client
entry.content: I eventually found the problem. If you want to install this silently, you need to use hdbinst.exe and not hdbsetup.exe

entry.title: Aggregation in RAP Custom Entity (Unmanaged Query) for Fiori List Report
entry.content:
I am working on a complex custom logic report that cannot be achieved using the standard CDS-based approach. Therefore, I decided to implement it using a RAP Custom Entity ‚Äì Unmanaged Query and display the results in a Fiori List Report.

In this List Report, I need to show totals and subtotals for certain amount columns. I tried adding annotations such as:

@OData.applySupportedForAggregation: #FULL
@Aggregation.default: #SUM

However, since this is a Custom Entity, aggregation annotations are not allowed.

I understand that I can implement aggregation logic directly in the query class select method, but for this to work the aggregation request must be triggered from the frontend UI. At the moment, this request is not being sent.

üëâ My questions are:

  • How can aggregation be enabled when creating a RAP-based Fiori List Report with a Custom Entity?
  • Is this feasible at all with Custom Entities, or do we need to handle it differently (e.g., via frontend UI extensions)?

Any guidance or best practices would be greatly appreciated. 

@Andre_Fischer

entry.title: Keep the blue side up: Building trust in AI through transparency (Responsible AI blogpost series)
entry.content:
Introduction

Flying has been a dream of humankind for ages, and how it can be achieved has tickled the minds of many visionaries and engineers. Part of the fascination is the possibility that humans push boundaries of what is physically possible. But physical laws are still in place, and accidents end fatally when something goes wrong, due to heights of dozens or thousands of meters or speeds needed for starts and landings. How much risk is the dream worth taking?

On December 17, 1903, Orville Wright conducted his historic flight with an airplane successfully. Just a few days earlier, Orville and his brother Wilbur had crashed in a test flight ‚Äì one of the first documented aviation accidents in history.

Today, many decades later, using aircrafts is considered one of the safest travel options (measured by distance traveled https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aviation_safety) ‚Äì thanks to curious engineers, learnings from accidents and incidents, scientific progress, publication of relevant regulations and industry standards, and of course an ever-attentive approach to safety and security checks and improvements. We can trust planes to be safe ‚Äì not per se (the owl Archimedes has a point here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KLI46yMdtmU) but because we have found ways to make them safe.

The fascination for machines that work similarly to the human mind has been around for ages. The potential of Artificial Intelligence (AI) for adding efficiency, creativity, and inspiration to persons‚Äô lives is immense. The nature of the technology brings also specific risks and can be scary: machines that reason and learn imply a loss of human control ‚Äì a challenge that is not only (science) fiction (HAL 9000 being just one example; for more see e. g. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_fiction) but reality (e. g. AIAAIC Incident Repository / Awful AI List / https://incidentdatabase.ai/ ).

Artificial intelligence has still a long way until it can be considered a matured technology which is as safe as air traffic has become. When it comes to AI today and going forward, we definitely want to trust, but verify: what are the implications when implementing a specific AI system; what is the system doing and why; in case of incidents: what was causing the issue; etc. Iteratively improving technical standards and procedural governance, considering ethical and legal requirements, will enhance safety for people, environment, and society going forward.

Every framework that discusses how to make AI systems safe for usage includes a section that has to do with transparency, including the UNESCO Recommendation of the Ethics of AI, SAP‚Äôs Guiding Principles for Artificial Intelligence, or the Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI by the High Level Expert Group on Artificial Intelligence set up by the European Commission (HLEG AI Ethics Guidelines).  

According to the HLEG AI Ethics Guidelines, ‚Äú[t]rustworthy AI has three components, which should be met throughout the system's entire life cycle: (1) it should be lawful, complying with all applicable laws and regulations (2) it should be ethical, ensuring adherence to ethical principles and values, and (3) it should be robust, both from a technical and social perspective.‚Äù Transparency requirements play a role in all three components, so let‚Äôs use these angles to have a closer look.

Lawful: Transparency requirements in regulatory and legal areas

In the 1920s, barnstorming and so-called flying circuses were very popular: stunt shows with daredevil pilots and acrobats executing spectacular and risky maneuvers with the plane (loopings etc.) and on the plane (wing walking). Early legislation related to civil air transportation addressed the most common causes of fatal accidents, including lack of pilot qualification and stunt practices that put the spectators‚Äô lives at risk. Over the years, laws were passed, updated, and complemented which intended to improve aviation safety and with that, the trust of the public in the technology, with the Air Commerce Act, issued in 1926, as an early example, and the Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2025/920 for sure not the last.

Defining and implementing regulation for technologies is inherently slower than the subject it is supposed to regulate. In the context of AI, luckily some laws that provide important guardrails to protect individuals have been in place for some time, or The California AI Transparency Act AB 853 are examples of regulation which targets the specific risks and challenges related to AI.

Individuals and legal entities have a need and partly also (will have) a right to transparency when it comes to decisions and AI; valid questions of stakeholders include: Which role does AI play in a decision that may affect my life going forward, and am I okay with that? Can I make an informed decision when I give consent to using an AI system as an individual? Do I have the transparency I need to diagnose the functioning / malfunctioning of an AI system, so that we can learn from issues and fix them going forward? How can Terms & Conditions help understand scope and limitations of AI systems?

Robust: Making AI systems secure and robust

Aircrafts are subject to thorough inspection based on sophisticated protocols that prove their respective airworthiness before they are permitted to operate. Insights from past incidents, e. g. through Flight Recorder data, are an important resource of input for improvements of hardware, software, or procedures, to help prevent future damage and harm.

Software systems need to be reliable in the sense that they work as designed and the potential risks related to their usage are minimized. Quality management, software security efforts and governance in general play a critical role when creating robust software.

The same applies to the development of AI systems, plus some extra aspects that have to do with the specific nature of those systems, in particular when they involve machine learning capabilities or are generating output autonomously (for definitions / distinctions of AI / ML / genAI / Agentic AI see e. g. the SAP AI Ethics Handbook).

What role does transparency play? For example, without transparency, testing AI system robustness and reliability are a critical challenge. At the same time, we are speaking of ‚Äòblack box‚Äô systems ‚Äì how can we even understand what is going on in the system and if that is what we expect in terms of reliability, security and safety?

Security testing of AI systems should not only look at the outcome or effect, but ideally have a certain level of insight in the processes and methods inside the system to identify root causes and potential systematic threats. Benchmarking of models or AI systems help understand / ‚Äòdiagnose‚Äô the quality and reliability and trigger mitigation as needed, runtime monitoring and traceability help prevent unintended and unwanted shifts in an AI system‚Äôs performance.

Software companies can leverage guidelines and recommendations (e. g. OWASP AI Testing Guide), applicable industry standards (i.e ISO 9001 Quality Management System, ISO/IEC 27001 Security Management System), and adjust and complement according to the specifics of e. g. the industry or the regional context. Documenting the compliance with relevant standards, including NIST AI Risk Management Framework RMF and ISO/IEC 42001 AI Management Systems, helps build trust in the responsible development of AI systems in customers (see e. g. the SAP Trust Center) and the general public.

Ethical: Human oversight

How come airplane engineers invent seatbelts for pilots and passengers, and why was there an affordance to adjust law and regulation to reduce accidents and harm related to air traffic? Costs related to damages and injuries may have played a role, but without doubt also: empathy and ethical considerations. Situations where people lose loved ones, suffer from severe injury or face damages to their property are something to be avoided, and there is a strong motivation to reduce risks leading to them and to strengthen the public‚Äôs trust in the technology and its operation.

Yes, there are AI-related legal requirements for transparency, and technical robustness is a prerequisite for AI systems that can be trusted. Relying on current or upcoming (known) regulation only when working on AI safety is not a sustainable approach: Technology is evolving too fast to allow regulatory processes to keep up and put legal boundaries in place. Thinking only in terms of current rules and potential gaps between them will turn legally compliant innovation into a ‚Äòjigsaw puzzle with moving parts‚Äô: Legal gaps you designed for may be closing in due course, and every new regulation poses a threat to the products in the portfolio or on the roadmap.

The ethical perspective on the other hand changes the focus from legal texts and fear of being sued, towards the vision to what we want the technology to do and what needs to be avoided. AI Ethics principles help inform legislation, but also provide guidance for technical innovation:

Not just do what is feasible, but think what is acceptable and desirable going forward, for us as individuals, for us as a company, and for us as a society.

One example: The HLEG AI Ethics Guidelines name fairness as an ethical imperative for trustworthy AI as early as 2016. SAP committed to fairness in the Guiding Principles for the Ethics of AI in 2018. The EU AI Act entered into force in 2024, with certain provisions applying immediately and others phased in over time, reaching full applicability by 2027.

Given the risks related to AI, we want to ensure that humans control AI systems as needed, and not the other way around. A prerequisite to ensure human agency and oversight: Transparency. You can‚Äôt control what you don‚Äôt know or understand. Measures like explainability, interpretability, and traceability are required to allow humans in their respective capacity and interaction with AI systems to stay in control, acquire knowledge, and gain trust and confidence that the AI is not creating any harm, neither to the individual, society, nor environment.

Different perspectives on transparency for responsible AI

The blogpost series will take the perspective of different stakeholders in the lifecycle of AI systems, including those who are ‚Äúdesigning, developing, deploying, implementing, using or being affected by AI‚Äù (HLEG AI Ethics Guidelines). SAP experts will shed light on different aspects and approaches, from a legal, a technical, or an ethical viewpoint, providing insights into challenges and solutions, considering organizational practices as well as user needs and customer expectations. Examples from real SAP use cases will illustrate the practical relevance and the efforts SAP is taking to build AI systems responsibly and create transparency so that stakeholders are enabled and empowered to understand risks and benefits, and execute on human oversight.

This blogpost will be updated with references whenever a new post is available to make it easy to get notified and find the information you are interested in.

Closing

When on an airplane, in most situations you would want to know that the skies are above you and the ground is beneath you (exceptions include flying circuses, see above). In any case, at least the pilot should know about the current orientation of the aircraft, even if weather conditions are blocking the sight of the actual surroundings. If the physical horizon is not visible, the attitude indicator, an instrument mimicking the blue skies above an artificial horizon and a brown ground below, will help adjust the plane‚Äôs orientation. Blue side up, brown side down means that the plane is not going astray, neither upwards nor downwards ‚Äì a means to keep orientation and an indicator of aviation safety.

We trust airplanes not because they are perfect and unbreakable. But because we know about their challenges, weaknesses, what to check, what to look at, how to optimize human-machine collaboration. And we have found ways to surface the information that is needed ‚Äì by pilots, by engineers, by passengers, or in other words: leverage transparency to foster safety.

Meaningful transparency is ‚Äòin the eye of the beholder‚Äô. Its design needs a human-centered approach to provide just the right angle, level, and amount of information that is relevant and helpful for individuals to interpret the situation, to ‚Äúmake sense, or derive meaning, from a given stimulus [‚Ä¶] so that the human can make a decision‚Äù (Broniatowski, 2021) ‚Äì a prerequisite for human oversight and trustworthy AI.

 

Let us share how AI transparency helps keep_the_blue_side_up. 

 

Stay tuned for the next post of the series about
Engineering AI Transparency!

 

 

 

References and further readings

Responsible AI challenges

  • AIAAIC Incident Repository
  • Awful AI List
  • https://incidentdatabase.ai/
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_fiction

Responsible AI guidelines

  • UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of AI: https://www.unesco.org/en/articles/recommendation-ethics-artificial-intelligence
  • SAP Guiding Principles for AI Ethics / Policy / Handbook: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-ethics.html
  • HLEG on Artificial Intelligence (European Commission) ‚Äì Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI: https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/library/ethics-guidelines-trustworthy-ai

Lawful

  • General Data Protection Regulation GDPR https://gdpr.eu/
  • European Union Artificial Intelligence Act (EU AI Act): https://artificialintelligenceact.eu/
    • https://artificialintelligenceact.eu/ai-act-explorer/
  • AB-853 California AI Transparency Act: https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=202520260AB853

Robust

  • ISO 9001 Quality Management System,
  • ISO/IEC 27001 Security Management System
  • ISO/IEC 42001 AI Management Systems
  • OWASP https://owasp.org/www-project-ai-testing-guide/ / https://owaspai.org/
  • NIST AI RMF https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework
  • SAP Trust Center: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center.html

Ethical

  • SAP Guiding Principles for AI Ethics / Policy / Handbook: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-ethics.html
  • Understandability blog post: https://community.sap.com/t5/artificial-intelligence-blogs-posts/trustworthy-ai-how-to-make-artificial-intelligence-understandable/ba-p/13576857
  • Broniatowski, D. A. (2021): Psychology of Explainability and Interpretability. https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ir/2021/NIST.IR.8367.pdf

entry.title: Base Salary Amount formatting in Offer Details templates
entry.content:
In Offer Details templates we use Base Salary Amount as a mandatory field where the recruiting can type/provide the annual/hourly based salary.

Even though, this fields has been configured as a currency, we notice that it is more an open space where number, letter and special signs can de captured. To ensure consistency, we are looking for the following format in this field.

$xxx,xxx.00 (annual) and $xx.xx (hourly).

entry.content:
It would be good to know data types of your variables.

But try to READ DATASET directly to variable typed as XSTRING and at once. Not in DO. ENDDO. loop. This way you will know exact size of binary data (xstrlen). I suspect there is some issue with appending the internal SOLIX table and converting from SOLIX table to xstring, but hard to guess.

Can you also compare the size of uploaded file (xstrlen) to the size which are you reading via DATASET? If the size is same, then the issue is somewhere else.

entry.title: SAP BN4L System Integration for GTT and Freight Collaboration with S/4HANA
entry.content:
SAP BN4L Systems Integration for GTT and Freight Collaboration with S/4HANA

 

 

System Overview and Architecture

SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) is SAP's new collaborative cloud network that empowers logistics businesses to work together more easily than ever before. It consists of the solutions and add-ons below. SAP Business Network for Logistics is a cloud-service solution based on SAP Business Technology Platform.

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (FC) improves supply chain efficiency by connecting business partners on a collaborative network that supports jointly managing transactions, exchanging documents, and sharing insights across the value chain. For instance, upon invitation from a shipper, a carrier can onboard onto the network and collaborate with shippers on freight tendering, invoicing, and milestone reporting.

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace (GTT) is a cloud-based solution that captures, processes, and stores tracking information about business processes, providing real-time transparency of logistics operations. It offers integration functionality with SAP TM and TM in S/4HANA for freight collaboration processes.

SAP Business Network for Logistics material traceability (MT) is a solution that provides end-to-end visibility into a product's journey from raw materials to finished goods. It uses "events" from your own and partner systems to create a complete genealogy of a batch, which helps with compliance, quality control, and more efficient product recalls.

 

Integration Architecture Diagram

 

Technical Integrations for Freight Collaboration & Global Track and Trace:

Enhancement for BN4L's Freight Collaboration Integration with S/4HANA

There are multiple standard interfaces which are used to communicate between BN4L Freight Collaboration and S/4 HANA system.

There are BADI‚Äôs being provided for such interfaces to enhance the same.

Some of the BADI‚Äôs are mentioned and its associated enhancement spot:

Enhancement Spot: /SCMTMS/TOR_SE_SPOT_TOR

 

For a better understanding here‚Äôs an example for the reference:

Example: If we want to check or update any data related to freight orders coming from BN4L at the time of order confirmation is done.

Solution:

We can implement the BADI /SCMTMS/TOR_SE_TORB_CONF and its following methods:

And we can add the code in Inbound_Processing method to as per requirement.

We can check from the payload under which tag have to check or update the data by getting payload from SRT_MONI and update the data under the relevant fields of the changing parameter of the method namely ‚ÄúOUT‚Äù.

 

 

Enhancement for BN4L's Global Track and Trace Integration with S/4HANA

To achieve this enhancement, we have to enhance standard GTT IDOC Extractor Class in which we can add our custom code.

For a better understanding here‚Äôs an example for the reference:

Example: If we want to send or update the carrier related details at the BN4L system which will provide a better visibility for tracking.

Solution:

We have created a POST-Exit enhancement in the GTT IDOC extractor class ZCL_GTT_STS_EF_PROCESSOR for method ZIF_GTT_STS_EF_PROCESSOR~GET_CONTROL_DATA.

 

In this we have to identify the field of the segment in which we have to update the values.

To get the segment fields we can refer to the class ZCL_GTT_STS_BO_FU_READER and navigate to its attribute section there we will find "CS_MAPPING"

In "CS_MAPPING" we can find all the segment fields which are part of IDOC.

 

There are other standard interfaces which are used to communicate between BN4L Global Track and Trace and S/4 HANA system. BADI‚Äôs being provided for such interfaces to enhance the same.

For a better understanding here‚Äôs an example scenario related to the events raised from GTT end.

Example: If we want to update the FO/FB related details in S/4 HANA system whenever a particular event is triggered from GTT system (e.g. CROSS_HANDOVER, HANDOVER etc).

Solution:

We can implement the following BADI and its required methods:

Enhancement Spot: /SCMTMS/SE_SPOT_TPEVT

BADI: /SCMTMS/SE_TPEVTNTF

And we can add the code in ADAPT_DATA_FOR_OMUH method to as per requirement.

We can check from the method signature the changing parameters in which we want to change/update the data based on the custom logic.

entry.title: How, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, to store and map the vendor/sender GLN
entry.content:
Hello support

We need to understand how to include the vendor (sending party) data in the outbound sales APIs, such as CO_EDI_INVOICE_REQUEST_OUT and CO_EDI_DELIVERY_REQUEST_OUT, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

  • In the classic DELVRY IDoc, this information was included in segment E1EDRM1 with qualifier OSO.
  • In the classic INVOIC IDoc, it was included in segment E1EDKA1 with qualifier LFL.
  • The GLN (Global Location Number) for the vendor/sender was maintained in table V_EAN_GLN, and the system would collect it from there to populate the respective segment in the IDoc.

We would like to know the recommended way to provide and extract this vendor/sender GLN information for the equivalent Party node in the outbound API payload. Which table or configuration is now used in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and how can we map this data so that it is displayed correctly in the output, analogous to how it worked previously with IDoc segments and V_EAN_GLN?

Thank you in advance for your guidance.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, to store and map th...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

This communication provides guidance on including vendor (sending party) data, specifically the Global Location Number (GLN), in outbound sales APIs such as CO_EDI_INVOICE_REQUEST_OUT and CO_EDI_DELIVERY_REQUEST_OUT in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

1. Background

In the previous SAP ECC system, outbound delivery and invoice messages included vendor/sender data in IDoc segments, and the GLN was sourced from a dedicated table.

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the IDoc framework and related tables are no longer used. Outbound APIs now rely on Business Partner master data as the source of vendor/sender information.

2. Recommended Approach Business Partner Master Data

  • The GLN must be maintained in the Business Partner (BP) master for the relevant vendor/sender.

  • Navigate to:
    Business Partner ‚Üí Identification ‚Üí Identification Type = GLN (91)

Maintaining the GLN here ensures that it is available for outbound API messages.

Outbound API Behavior

  • The APIs CO_EDI_DELIVERY_REQUEST_OUT and CO_EDI_INVOICE_REQUEST_OUT automatically read the GLN from the Business Partner master data.

  • The GLN is populated in the Party node of the API payload corresponding to the appropriate sender/vendor role.

  • No additional mapping or configuration is required for outbound processing.

Clarification on External-to-Internal Partner Conversion

  • Any configuration used for inbound message mapping of external partner identifiers to internal Business Partner numbers is not required for outbound APIs.

3. Recommended Steps

  1. Open the relevant Business Partner representing the vendor/sender.

  2. Navigate to Identification ‚Üí Add Identification Number.

  3. Select Identification Type = GLN (91).

  4. Enter the correct GLN.

  5. Save the Business Partner.

  6. Trigger the outbound delivery or invoice API. The Party node will now include the GLN automatically.

4. Summary

By maintaining the GLN in the Business Partner master data, the system automatically populates the correct vendor/sender information in outbound delivery and invoice APIs. This approach replaces the previous ECC IDoc logic and aligns with S/4HANA Public Cloud best practices.

 

Best Regards

Aishwarya

entry.title: Restoring Transport Routes After System Refresh ‚Äì Edit Option Disabled in STMS
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

Greetings! I hope you are all doing well.

During a recent System Refresh activity, I encountered an issue where the Transport Route configuration could not be edited in the Quality system after restoring a backup from the Production system. Since this issue can occur frequently during refresh cycles, I am sharing the root cause, analysis, and step-by-step resolution.

Issue Summary: -

After performing a backup restore from Production to Quality, we executed the standard post-refresh activities‚Äîone of which includes clearing the existing TMS configuration in the target (Quality) system.

However, once the system came up and I launched STMS, the Edit / Change icon was disabled, preventing me from defining or modifying the transport routes.

 

 

Because the Quality system was refreshed from Production, the original routes and controller information were overwritten or removed‚Äîleading to a mismatch between the local TMS configuration and the domain controller.

Root Cause:-

During the system refresh:

  • Transport Management System (TMS) data from Production overwrote the Quality system‚Äôs configuration.
  • As part of cleanup, TMS routes were deleted or became inconsistent.
  • The system lost its connection to the Domain Controller, causing the edit icon in STMS Transport Routes to become unavailable.

Essentially, the Quality system was no longer recognized as part of the transport domain.

Technical Explanation: -

After the refresh:

  • The refreshed system contains production TMSADM keys, not matching the domain controller.
  • Therefore, the system cannot authenticate with the domain controller.
  • As a result, STMS ‚Üí Transport Routes goes into read-only mode.

To synchronize the system again, we must update the local TMS config with the domain controller.

Solution ‚Äì Restore TMS Route Using ‚ÄúAdjust with Controller: -

Perform the steps in the Quality system:

Step 1: Log in with DDIC user in client 000

This is mandatory because TMS configuration changes can only be done in:

  • Client 000
  • With DDIC or TMSADM authorized users

Step 2: Execute Transaction STMS

The system will try to connect to the domain controller.

STMS T-code

Step 3: Navigate to Transport Routes

Step 4: Adjust Configuration with Domain Controller

Go to: Configuration>Adjust with controller

You will notice the Edit icon is disabled.

Then click on configuration and get option is adjust with controller just see below snap.

 

Click Yes when prompted.

This action forces the Quality system to:

  • Re-import TMS configuration from the Domain Controller
  • Regenerate TMSADM RFC connection
  • Restore the correct system role (Dev ‚Üí QA ‚Üí Prod)
  • Load the existing route definitions

Step 5: Save the Transport Route

  • After synchronization, the correct routes appear automatically.
  • Click Save to activate the configuration.

Additional Technical Checks (Optional but Recommended)

  1. Verify RFC connection of TMSADM

         SM59 ‚Üí ABAP Connections ‚Üí TMSADM_<SID>_XXX

         Status should be green.

  1. Check Domain Controller system

         In Domain Controller (usually DEV system):
         STMS ‚Üí Overview ‚Üí Systems

          Ensure the refreshed system is visible and status is Active.

  1. Check consistency

       Run:

       STMS ‚Üí System Overview ‚Üí Extras ‚Üí Verify Configuration

Conclusion

After a system refresh, you may find the Edit option disabled in STMS due to mismatched TMS configuration. Using ‚ÄúAdjust with Controller‚Äù is the correct approach to synchronize the system with the transport domain controller and restore the predefined routes.

This process ensures that:

  • Quality system aligns with the domain controller
  • Routes are restored without manual reconstruction
  • TMS remains consistent and operational

 

Thanks for Reading!

Please feel free to share your thoughts, improvements, or any similar experiences you‚Äôve encountered during system refreshes.

Regards,

Nishant Garg

entry.title: Re: TrackID in consumer API for order tracking (FC)
entry.content:
The consumer API sends out a tracking request from BN4L to the recipient (carrier, VP).

BN4L cannot anticipate the unique tracking ID that is being generated by the recipient post receiving a request. Thus, this information cannot be mandatory.

In reverse, it has to be mandatory when receiving back the response from the recipient for reference purposes along the tracking process.

entry.title: XPRAS Error During MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG in S/4HANA Conversion Execution Phase
entry.content:
During the recent Oracle ‚Üí HANA system conversion to S/4HANA 2023, we encountered an error in the Execution Phase where SUM stopped with an error at the step MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG.

Overview

During the SUM execution, the process stopped in MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG due to BW-related inconsistencies. The phase could not continue because certain BW InfoObjects were not fully activated before downtime.

 

Analysis

  • While reviewing the error logs (XPRASUPG_NEW.ELG and related BW activation logs), we observed multiple failures related to InfoObject activation.
  • The XPRAS engine failed to merge certain BW objects because the BW content was not in an active state before SUM was started.
  • We validated client settings, checked multiple profiles, reviewed shadow logs, and compared BW content activation status before correlating this with the root cause.
  • Only after detailed log review and cross-checking, it became clear that the system required specific BW preparation activities prior to downtime.

How to Identify

These indicators helped confirm the issue early:

  1. XPRAS error in XPRASUPG_NEW.ELG with BW InfoObject activation entries.
  2. Multiple failed entries referring to missing or inactive InfoObjects.
  3. BW task list not executed before downtime (SAP_BW_SETUP_INITIAL_S4HANA).
  4. Running STC01 or RSDG_IOBJ_ACTIVATE manually showed several inactive objects.
  5. SUM repeating the same activation attempts and stopping again.

This combination confirmed that BW content activation was incomplete prior to the conversion.

Resolution

After confirming the root cause, we performed the below steps to fix the issue:

  1. Implemented the required corrections in Client 000 using a non-DDIC user with SAP_ALL.
  2. Activated the missing BW InfoObjects as per SAP Note 3315495.
  3. Ensured the system was locked again and resumed the SUM execution.
  4. SUM continued successfully without further XPRAS errors.

Workaround (for early detection )

To prevent the issue in the next conversion cycles (QA/DR/Production):

  • Implement SAP Notes 3305016 and 3316148 before executing SUM.
    ‚Ä¢ Before downtime, run task list:
    STC01 ‚Üí SAP_BW_SETUP_INITIAL_S4HANA
  • Optionally run:
    Program RSDG_IOBJ_ACTIVATE to ensure all InfoObjects are active.
  • Validate BW readiness in Sandbox during rehearsal runs.

These actions ensure the BW layer is fully consistent before SUM execution begins.

Regards,
Shubham Mishra

entry.title: Generic XI Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline
entry.content:
With the latest version update 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration package, we have added a generic XI outbound processing flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI. It's shipped with the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound. You can use the generic XI outbound flow for both asynchronous as well as synchronous communication using the XI message protocol. See Introducing a new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages.

Intro

The generic XI outbound processing flow is actually not replacing the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07), it is an additional step (Step 08) in the rows of pipeline steps for handling the connection to receiver systems using the XI protocol. So, in step 07 you define your scenario-specific mappings and then call step 08 via ProcessDirect adapter. Step 08 acts then as XI receiver channel to dynamically connecting to the backend systems.

This new feature was done per customer's request to standardize and ease the configuration of XI outbound scenarios. With this, you are able to dynamically connect to the backend, set monitoring headers in a common way, and store adapter connectivity logic in one place.

It was also done because we quite often noticed that the XI receiver adapter was wrongly setup in terms of delivery assurance. In the new XI outbound processing integration flow, the delivery assurance in the receiver adapter is properly setup using the UniqueID header which is passed from the pipeline. By default, the UniqueID equals the Message Processing Log ID of the generic outbound processing flow (Step 06) which takes care of dispatching messages to the scenario-specific flows and eventually restarting failed messages. You also have the option to modify the UniqueID header in the scenario-specific outbound flow if you prefer to use a unique ID from the message payload. In any case, a unique ID will be automatically used by the XI receiver adapter ensuring Exactly Once delivery.

Configuration Options

As said, you dynamically configure the XI receiver adapter parameters and the XI header attributes during runtime. For this, different options are supported as outlined in the XI Receiver Adapter help documentation. Combining the options is also supported.

  • You can create and maintain message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow (Step 07).
  • You can create and maintain the parameters in the Partner Directory.
  • You can configure the externalized parameters of the generic XI outbound integration flow (Step 08).

We distinguish between XI connection parameters and XI message headers (scenario related).

  • Because XI headers are scenario-specific (e.g. Service Interface name), you would configure them either as message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow or as string parameters in the Partner Directory for the partner ID representing the configuration scenario.
  • The configuration of connection parameters depends on your chosen approach. You may define receiver-specific XI outbound flows by copying the Cloud Integration Pipeline ‚Äì Generic Outbound package. This allows you to create an individual XI Step 08 flow for each XI receiver and in this case, you would configure the connection parameters as externalized parameters of the copied generic XI outbound integration flow. Otherwise, if you used one single generic XI outbound integration flow across all scenarios and all receivers, you would maintain string parameters in the Partner Directory for the partner ID representing the business component or configure them as message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow Step 07.

Sample Scenario

This blog post intends to explain the different options in more detail along sample scenarios. In the Partner Directory, we have setup a configuration scenario of pattern Content-Based-Router with 2 sender systems and 3 receiver systems. On the Alternative Partners tab, we map the sender system names, the sender interface name and the sender interface namespace to our configuration scenario, here CS_PIP_Samples_Scenario_02E. Actually, on the sender side we also use the XI protocol, so those parameters are part of the XI header of the message sent to Cloud Integration. In the generic XI inbound flow we then determine the partner ID of the configuration scenario based on the alternative partner defined.

Each receiver is differently configured to be able to cover all options mentioned above. On tab Binary Parameters, we have uploaded a binary containing the XSLT which is carried out to determine the receivers based on XPath conditions.

In the XSLT, you can see that for the 3 receivers we call different scenario-specific outbound processing flows.

Option 1: Message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow

The first receiver, in our case BS_02E_R1, uses the first option by maintaining message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow. As you can see below, the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific outbound processing flow is the one maintained in the XSLT in case that the supplier equals ABCD and the country equals DE.

In a content modifier step, we have maintained the connection parameters like credential alias, authentication method, proxy type and XI endpoint of the receiver system as well as the XI headers SAP_ReceiverInterface and SAP_ReceiverInterfaceNamespace as message headers. The headers SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline. Optionally, you can override them here. All message headers are then passed to the generic XI outbound flow. For the detailed parameter names, refer to XI Receiver Adapter.

We then call the generic XI outbound flow via ProcessDirect adapter. Here, we need to enter the endpoint of the generic XI outbound flow.

By default, the endpoint of the generic XI outbound flow equals /generic/step08/xi. You can change to your own preferences. We kept the default.

Finally, we sent a sample message to the pipeline. In the message monitor you find all log entries that belong to the same exchanged message. You can filter on the log entries by selecting the Correlation ID link. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc.

By the way, the actual sender and receiver names are BS_02E_S1Q and BS_02E_R1Q, respectively, because we run the scenario on the Quality Assurance environment. Those names are then mapped to alias names which are used within the pipeline, e.g., in the XSLT. See next chapter where we show how to setup the support for different landscape stages for the involved business systems.

 

Option 2: Parameters in the Partner Directory

The second receiver, here BS_02E_R2, uses the second option by maintaining the Partner Directory parameters. The corresponding scenario-specific outbound processing flow has the ProcessDirect endpoint configured as maintained in the XSLT above for the case that the supplier equals EFGH and for any country other than DE. Here, we do not need to create any message headers and we forward the message to the generic XI outbound flow with default endpoint like in the option before.

As mentioned above, you can maintain both in the Partner Directory XI headers and connection parameters. For the connection parameters we need to define a partner ID representing the business system. We need this anyway to map from the actual business system name to the alias name. We actually did this for all systems involved in the configuration scenarios. As an example the screenshot below shows the partner ID with the alias name BS_02E_R2. In the Alternative Partners tab, we map the actual names to the alias depending on the landscape stage, e.g., for QA the actual name is BS_02E_R2Q. If you like to know more about how to setup the support for different landscape stages, check out Landscape Stages.

On the String Parameters tab of the System Alias, we have maintained the XI connection parameters i.e. proxy type, authentication method, credential alias, and XI endpoint of the receiver system. The naming convention is to add the actual system name as suffix to the parameter names. Here, we only did this for the QA landscape, usually you would then also maintain the string parameters for the other landscapes. By the way, this business system alias can be used across different configuration scenarios and hence you can reuse those connection settings. For the detailed parameter names, refer to XI Receiver Adapter.

The XI headers are scenario-specific and hence they are maintained as string parameters of the configuration scenario. For the InterfaceNameDetermination parameter add the receiver system alias as suffix. For the InterfaceNamespaceDetermination parameter add the interface name that you defined before as suffix (the namespace can also be determined dynamically in Step 08 by evaluating an XPath expression against the XML payload; however, this requires that the payload‚Äôs namespace matches the namespace of the corresponding Service Interface). The other XI headers SAP_SenderParty, SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface, SAP_ReceiverParty and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline.

When sending a sample message to the pipeline, you can monitor the exchanged message in the message monitor. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc. Here we actually also use a party for the receiver system, see XSLT above.

 

Option 3: Configuring the generic XI outbound integration flow

The third receiver, here BS_02E_R3, uses the third option i.e. an own generic XI outbound integration flow. In this case, we need to create a copy of the generic XI outbound integration flow and configure the connection parameters as externalized parameters of the copied flow. It is important not to directly copy the integration flow but rather copy the standard package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound that we provide on the SAP Accelerator Business Hub. This way, you ensure that the copied integration flow still receives updates if any.

So, in the Discover area of your tenant, search for the package and then select Copy.

In the upcoming dialog, you are informed that the package already exists, so select Create copy.

Then maintain a package suffix, here BS.02ER3 indicating that this is a business system specific package, then select OK. All integration flows of the copied package get the suffix added to their IDs as well.

When switching to the Design area, you should see the copied package.

In the copied package, configure the Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI flow. Before you are able to deploy the flow, you need to change its ProcessDirect endpoint. This needs to be unique across the tenant.

Furthermore, on tab More we configure the XI connection parameters. Note, those are actually default values. They are only applied if not otherwise defined i.e. as message headers or in the Partner Directory. For this receiver, this is not the case so we ensure that those default values are used.

The corresponding scenario-specific outbound processing flow has the ProcessDirect endpoint configured as maintained in the XSLT above for the case that no receiver could be determined, see above.

We do need to at least maintain the XI headers SAP_ReceiverInterface and SAP_ReceiverInterfaceNamespace as message headers. The headers SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline.

In order to call the copied generic XI outbound flow, we need to enter its ProcessDirect endpoint as configured above.

When sending a sample message to the pipeline, you can monitor the exchanged message in the message monitor. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc.

Unfortunately, the copied XI outbound flow name is kept unchanged. You need to scroll down to the Artifacts Details section to see its integration flow ID which contains the suffix.

Hope this helps you set up your XI outbound scenarios using the new generic XI outbound flow of the Cloud Integration Pipeline. If you are missing any XI-specific processing capabilities that would be useful for such a generic XI receiver flow, feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Good to Know

Outbound processing for XI is designed around the XI receiver adapter‚Äôs capability to manage Quality of Service at the Integration Flow level. When this processing mode is enabled, the outbound connection can only be created from a Message End event. This means that Request-Reply or Send steps cannot be used, and the XI call will always appear as the final processing step in the main integration process. Because of this limitation, it is not possible to set custom headers containing the XI Message ID generated in the receiver XI system for end-to-end tracking. To address this, we recommend adding a Content Modifier in your Step 07 to store custom headers with the XI Message ID and then attach these headers to the message processing log using the script from the Pipeline v2 - Script Collection.

entry.title: Re: How to customize push notification payload to send additional data from s/4 to SSAM
entry.content: @daniyal_dolare I tested via IW21 in SAP GUI, Create Maintenance Request in Fiori, and Create Maintenance Notification in Fiori. In all scenarios I see the notification in the table by the time BUILD_JSON_DATA is executed. If this truly won't work for you, another option is to change the criteria that triggers the push. If you trigger the push when the notification is put in process or approved rather than created you should have access to the data you want. You can control this via the SAMXXXX_NOTIFICATION_PUSH exchange object.

entry.title: Re: BTP service plan "Process Integration Runtime" and Cl...
entry.content:
In Integration Suite there are only 2 commercial metrics

1) Tenant cost (flat fixed cost to "turn on" Integration Suite

2) Message cost (dynamic cost based on consumption)

Cloud Foundry (CF) is the underlying platform for BTP Multi-Cloud, and you are "enabling" the related access points in CF to be made available (e.g. CF CLI APIs). This has no cost as it is merely enabling access. 

Once this has been done, you can activate the Process Integration Runtime service, which is again, a part of the CF governance mechanism, to generate Service Keys for access to the runtime. There is no cost to be able to access your service.

Hope this helps others as well.

Regards,
Elijah
